Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a message from my sister: “Don’t forget, dinner’s at 6! Can’t wait to celebrate!” She’d just landed her first job, and our family was gathering to make her feel special. As her brother, I knew how much this meant to her—she’d always been there for me, and I wanted to show her the same support. But then my calendar pinged, reminding me of my volunteer shift at the community center, also starting at 6. I was expected to be on time, to set an example for the newer volunteers. Still, I knew the others could handle things if I was a bit late, but I also didn’t want to let the team down. My chest tightened as I weighed the disappointment in my sister’s eyes against the responsibility I felt toward my fellow volunteers. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I found myself frozen, torn between being the brother my sister needed and the volunteer my team relied on.
